Description: Rim sherd of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery stemmed bowl; white slip; interior and top of rim reserved; exterior: short diagonal strokes on outside of rim; two lines at edge top of wall; black-figure decoration consisting of lion to left (head, forehead, mane and raised foreleg remaining; red on top-knot and mane); at left, undetermined black (fired red) motif; blob as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in Group E of the Sphinx and Lion Style. The vases in this group are the latest in the series of the Sphinx and Lion Style and the execution of the imagery is done in a hurried manner with no attention to detail. The figures are sketchy and, in some cases, difficult to identify. Lemos also places this sherd in Stage 1 of Group D of the Sphinx and Lion Style. Although the imagery is lively, the execution of the figures is loose and careless and the rosettes clumsy, but soince there is no rosette on this sherd, it is difficult to place it in Group D. As Group E marks a deterioration of the style, even if the imagery on the sherd is restricted, the sherd might best be placed in Lemos's Group E.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 148, p. 311, no. 1297, pl. 167)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2129) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
